channel.title: Bloomberg Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Tax Bill Would Add $3.3 Trillion to US Deficits, CBO Says
item.description: The Senate version of President Donald Trump’s tax and spending measure would add nearly $3.3 trillion to US deficits over a decade, according to a new estimate from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard

media:content.media:description: The rotunda of the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. US House Speaker Mike Johnson said he is fighting to maintain the new $40,000 cap on state and local deductions in the draft tax bill now before the Senate, where Republicans are seeking to enact a less generous break.

item.title: Trump Deals Poised to Fall Short of Sweeping Global Trade Reform
item.description: With just 10 days to go until President Donald Trump’s country-specific tariffs are set to resume, the White House appears poised to fall short of the sweeping global trade reforms it promised to achieve during the three months they were on hold.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, center, following trade talks at Lancaster House in London, UK, on June 9.

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Hits Senate With GOP Torn by Competing Demands
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune is rushing to meet President Donald Trump’s July 4 deadline for pushing through his massive tax and spending bill, but first he has to work through a list of approximately eight Republican senators who have expressed opposition to portions of it.
item.dc:creator: Laura Davison, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune

item.title: Senate GOP Restores Medicaid Cuts to Trump Tax Package
item.description: Senate Republicans restored major Medicaid cuts to Donald Trump’s signature economic legislation, re-fashioning a key provision to overcome a procedural obstacle.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang, Erin Durkin

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune

item.title: Tillis Won’t Seek Reelection After Trump Primary Threat
item.description: North Carolina Senator Thom Tillis said he won’t seek reelection following a primary threat from President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Laura Davison, Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senator Thom Tillis Photographer: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg

item.title: Indian Official Says Political ‘Constraints’ Led to Jet Losses
item.description: India’s political leadership didn’t permit strikes on Pakistani military bases at the start of hostilities between the two countries in May, allowing Islamabad to shoot down its fighter jets, according to a military official.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Residents look at a wreckage of an unknown aircraft in Wuyan area of Pampore, near Srinagar, Kashmir on May 7, 2025.

item.title: Mamdani Says He’d Rather Have a World Without Billionaires
item.description: Democratic mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani said Sunday that billionaires shouldn’t exist, stepping up his rhetoric in a network television interview against the wealthiest and most powerful New Yorkers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Fisher

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani, New York City mayoral candidate, during a campaign event at the NAN House of Justice in the Harlem neighborhood of New York, US, on Saturday, June 28, 2025. The 33-year-old Queens assemblyman is seeking to consolidate support ahead of the November election, where he'll face off against incumbent Mayor Eric Adams and potentially his chief rival in the primary, Andrew Cuomo, both of whom would run on independent tickets.

item.title: US Envoy Sees F-35 Issue With Turkey Resolved Soon, Anadolu Says
item.description: The US ambassador to Turkey said a resolution to a long-running F-35 dispute between the NATO allies is possible by the end of the year, signaling a potential breakthrough in a yearslong standoff that has strained defense ties.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: Tom Barrack

item.title: Trump Tax Bill Advances in Senate as GOP Scrounges for Votes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s $4.5 trillion tax cut bill prevailed in a crucial Senate test vote after hours of negotiations, setting up a fresh round of deal-making as Republicans seek to convince holdouts to support the bill for final passage.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: US Vice President JD Vance at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, June 28, 2025. President Donald Trump’s $4.5 trillion tax cut bill prevailed in a crucial Senate test vote, a sign that Republican leaders are resolving the infighting over portions of the legislation and moving toward meeting a July 4 deadline the president has set for passage.

item.title: Trump Says There’s a Buyer for TikTok But Won’t Divulge Name
item.description: President Donald Trump said he has identified a buyer for the US operations of TikTok social media app owned by Chinese company ByteDance Ltd., but he won’t provide details for two weeks.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: The TikTok app page in the Google Play store on a smartphone arranged in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025. The Supreme Court signaled it's likely to uphold a law that would ban the popular TikTok social media platform in the US if it isn't sold by its Chinese parent company by Jan. 19.

item.title: Trump Says Iran Might Get Sanctions Relief If It Can Be Peaceful
item.description: President Donald Trump suggested he might back eventual sanctions relief for Iran “if they can be peaceful,” combining threats and the prospect of diplomacy after US strikes aimed at destroying Iranian nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: A national flag of Islamic Republic of Iran on the wall of the Glass Building that came under Israeli missile attack in Tehran, Iran on June 25, 2025.

item.title: Trump Says He Doesn’t Expect to Extend July 9 Tariff Deadline
item.description: President Donald Trump said he doesn’t think he’ll need to extend the July 9 trade deadline he has imposed on countries to secure deals with the US to avoid higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump

item.title: Musk Fumes as Trump Tax Bill Cuts Electric Vehicle Credits
item.description: Elon Musk slammed the US Senate’s latest version of President Donald Trump’s multi-trillion dollar tax bill Saturday, warning that the cuts to electric vehicle and other clean energy credits would be “incredibly destructive” to the country.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce.

item.title: Serbia Says China Has Promised Stellantis Critical Minerals Help
item.description: Serbia has received assurances from China that it would support speeding up exports of materials critical for electric-vehicle production, benefiting companies like Stellantis NV, which operates a factory in the Balkan country, President Aleksandar Vucic said on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A new Fiat Grande Panda EV model automobile in a cradle on the production line at the Stellantis NV manufacturing plant in Kragujevac, Serbia, on Monday, July 22, 2024. Fully electric and hybrid variants of the Grande Panda are planned for Serbian production. Photographer: Oliver Bunic/Bloomberg

item.title: China to Allow Resumption of Some Seafood Imports From Japan
item.description: China said it will allow the import of some seafood products from Japan to resume, a partial lifting of the blanket ban imposed following Tokyo’s release of wastewater from a wrecked nuclear power plant in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam

media:content.media:description: A plate of tuna sushi at Yoshitsune sushi restaurant in Urayasu, Japan, on Monday, Dec. 5, 2022. Soaring tuna prices are among the items driving Japan’s fastest inflation in four decades and a fall in purchasing power that are together testing the limits of the country’s outlier policy mix. At Yoshitsune, the days of buying raw tuna are gone as the restaurant buys it frozen to stay on budget.

item.title: Chile Votes in Primary Thrown Open by Rising Communist Candidate
item.description: Chileans head to the polls on Sunday in a presidential primary for left-wing candidates, a contest thrown open by a late rally in support for a communist contender.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara casts a ballot at a polling station during Chile’s presidential primary election in Santiago on June 29.

item.title: Putin Expands Secrecy Law to Tighten Wartime Control in Russia
item.description: President Vladimir Putin has expanded the range of information covered by Russia’s state secrecy law, further tightening his grip on society as his war in Ukraine continues.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: A surveillance camera operates in Red square near the Kremlin as night falls in Moscow, Russia, on Saturday, Nov. 2, 2019. The public-private network of as many as 200,000 cameras in Moscow records 1.5 billion hours of footage a year that can be accessed by 16,000 government employees, intelligence officers and law-enforcement personnel.

item.title: LNG Tanker Leaves Sanctioned Russian Plant Bound for Murmansk
item.description: A liquefied gas tanker, which docked at Russia’s sanctioned Arctic LNG 2 plant last week, appears to have left the facility and is heading toward the northern port of Murmansk, according to ship-tracking data on the Bloomberg terminal.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: The liquefied natural gas (LNG) tanker Sohshu Maru, right, next to loading arms, left, at Jera Co.'s Futtsu Thermal Power Station in Futtsu, Chiba Prefecture, Japan, on Friday, Dec. 17, 2021. North Asia spot LNG prices hovered near $40/mmbtu, with buyers in the region satisfied by inventory levels heading into winter, while European prices traded at a premium to Asian values for a third day. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Iran Says It Doubts Truce Will Hold, Warns Against New Strikes
item.description: Iran said it remains skeptical that a tentative US-brokered ceasefire with Israel would last, warning it’s prepared to respond to any fresh aggression.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: Mourners carry the flag-draped coffin of an Iranian soldier killed in an Israeli strike days ago, during his funeral procession in Tehran on June 26, 2025. Iran reopened on June 25 the airspace over the country's east, state media reported, following a ceasefire with Israel that ended 12 days of fighting. (Photo by AFP) (Photo by -/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Hungary Says US Lifts Sanctions on Its Nuclear Expansion Project
item.description: The US government has lifted sanctions that had held up Hungary’s planned expansion of its Paks nuclear plant, Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: Workers prepare the ground for the substructure of the fifth and sixth blocks of the Paks 2 nuclear power plant near Paks, Hungary on October 9, 2024. The two new nuclear power plant blocks, with reactors to be supplied by Russia's Rosatom, will each have a capacity of 1,200 megawatts/hour. (Photo by ATTILA KISBENEDEK / AFP) (Photo by ATTILA KISBENEDEK/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Indian Negotiators Extend US Stay as Trade Talks Gather Pace
item.description: India’s trade team has extended its stay in Washington to iron out differences as the two sides look to clinch a deal before a July 9 deadline when higher US tariffs are set to kick in, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers stacked on a container ship at Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Tariffs Threaten Fed With Real Inflation Headache, BIS Says
item.description: Resurgent US inflation could unfold as the world economy reels from Donald Trump’s disruptive trade policies, the Bank for International Settlements warned.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Shoppers carry bags in the Chinatown neighborhood of San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal consumption figures on June 27.

item.title: Serbia Arrests Dozens After Clashes at Anti-Government Rally
item.description: Serbian police clashed with anti-government protesters after tens of thousands rallied in Belgrade demanding an early election to remove President Aleksandar Vucic and his governing party.
item.dc:creator: Misha Savic

media:content.media:description: A flare burns as Serbian Riot Police move towards protesters as tens of thousands gather in central Belgrade to issue an "ultimatum" to the populist government to call early elections after months of student-led strikes across the country, in Belgrade, on June 28, 2025. Anti-graft protests have rocked the Balkan nation since November when 16 people were killed in the northern city of Novi Sad by a train station roof collapse, a tragedy widely blamed on entrenched corruption. For over half a year, students have blockaded universities and organised large demonstrations around the country, demanding a transparent investigation into the tragedy with their focus shifting after little action from authorities to call for early parliamentary elections. (Photo by OLIVER BUNIC / AFP) (Photo by OLIVER BUNIC/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Ukraine Reports Record Russian Missile and Drone Attack
item.description: Ukraine said Russia fired a record 537 missiles and drones in “massive” overnight attacks.
item.dc:creator: Kateryna Chursina

media:content.media:description: A policeman inspects debris at the bottom of a multi-storey residential building, which was damaged after a Russian drone attack in Odesa on June 28, 2025, amid the Russian invasion of Ukraine. A Russian drone strike on Ukraine's southern port city of Odesa killed two people and wounded 14, including children, local authorities said. Moscow has stepped up drone and missile attacks on Ukraine and peace talks initiated by the United States to end the three-year conflict have stalled. (Photo by Oleksandr GIMANOV / AFP) (Photo by OLEKSANDR GIMANOV/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: OLEKSANDR GIMANOV/AFP

item.title: UK Welfare Overhaul Back on Track After Concessions, Minister Says
item.description: The UK government expressed confidence it can win a crucial parliamentary vote of its disputed flagship welfare reform policy following a U-turn by Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Shiyin Chen, Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: Wes Streeting, UK health secretary, departs following a cabinet meeting ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer's government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power.

item.title: France Confident Tariff Deal Can Be Reached Before Deadline
item.description: French finance minister Eric Lombard said the European Union can clinch some form of a trade agreement with the US before a July 9 deadline, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard

item.title: Israeli Gas Flows to Egypt Return to Normal as Iran Truce Holds
item.description: Israeli natural gas flows to Egypt returned to normal levels after a truce with Iran allowed the Jewish state to reopen facilities shuttered by the 12-day conflict.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

item.title: Chants of 'Death to the IDF' at Glastonbury 'Appalling,' Streeting Says
item.description: Wes Streeting has said chants of "death" to the Israel Defence Forces (IDF) at Glastonbury were "appalling" and that the BBC and festival have "questions to answer".

media:content.media:description: Crowds watch Kneecap performing on the West Holts Stage during the Glastonbury Festival at Worthy Farm in Somerset. Picture date: Saturday June 28, 2025. (Photo by Ben Birchall/PA Images via Getty Images)

item.title: Measures to Ease Inflation Must be Speedy, Says Japan’s Ishiba
item.description: Any measures to ease inflation in Japan must be speedy and shouldn’t impede the government’s ability to fund social services, Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said on Sunday, in a comment reflecting his aversion to sales tax cuts as opposition parties campaign to lower the duty ahead of a key election next month.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shoppers cross a street in the Ginza district of Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Japan's cabinet office will release a monthly consumer confidence survey on April 9.

item.title: Korea’s Lee Nominates Finance Minister to Tackle Growth, Trade
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung nominated Koo Yun-cheol as the next finance minister, turning to a veteran bureaucrat to guide the economy at a time of sluggish growth and mounting trade pressures from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Myungshin Cho

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung, South Korea's president, delivers a speech at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. South Korea urgently drafted a supplementary budget to address the "pressing" challenges facing the economy, Lee said. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg
